intro: Betula alba var. urticifolia, commonly known as the stinging nettle birch, is a variant of the white birch characterized by its distinctive leaves that resemble those of the stinging nettle. It is a deciduous tree native to Europe and parts of Asia, typically found in moist, shaded woodland areas. The leaves are serrated and often have a reddish underside, while the bark is smooth and pale, with a tendency to peel in thin layers. This variety is known for its ecological importance, providing habitat and food for various insects and wildlife. Its unique appearance and ecological role make it a notable species within its native range.
